title: How to Improve an Old Concrete Patio

steps.headline: Hose down the patio with water to remove all dirt and oil.
steps.description: You can use a standard garden hose, but for tougher jobs you might consider using a pressure washer. Set the pressure between 2000 PSI and 3000 PSI--anything lower won't be as effective in cleaning, and anything higher may damage your concrete. If you are using a pressure washer, wear gloves and safety glasses for protection from the high-pressure water and/or loose debris.

steps.headline: Scrub the patio using a cleaning solution and a bristle brush.
steps.description: Start cleaning the patio by pouring a mild all-purpose cleaner like Mr. Clean or Simple Green on the area and scrubbing with a bristle brush. A hand brush would work for smaller areas, but for larger areas, you may want to consider using a push broom. For really tough dirt and stains, use a stronger cleaner like bleach or specially-formulated concrete cleaner. Be sure to protect any surrounding grass or plants because the chemicals can harm them. For an effective natural cleaner, try mixing equal parts of vinegar and water and using in place of the other cleaners.

steps.headline: Rinse the patio with water to remove all cleaning solution.
steps.description: Use your garden hose or pressure washer, paying close attention to areas near housing and other structures, and places that tend to puddle.

steps.headline: Consider applying a concrete sealer for added benefits.
steps.description: Sealing your patio will enhance the visual appeal by adding a glossy, “like new” finish, and will protect the area from further staining and damage. You can purchase a concrete sealer for about $30.00 a gallon (3.8L) online or at your local home improvement store.

steps.headline: Purchase a concrete stain at your local home improvement store.
steps.description: You can check online for more colors, and some brands offer customizable, tinting options. The stain will cost you between $30.00 and $50.00 per gallon (3.8L), which will cover approximately 250 square feet (23 m).

steps.headline: Wash your patio to remove dirt and grime and allow it to dry.
steps.description: Use an all-purpose product like Mr. Clean or Simple Green for the cleaning. Try a solution of equal parts of vinegar and water for an all-natural option. Mix the solution in a large bucket. Use a small scrub brush to dip in the bucket, or pour a little bit of the solution directly on the patio and use a broom to firmly scrub the concrete. For areas with tough stains, pour a bit of full-strength cleaner onto the area. Allow it to sit for 2-3 minutes before scrubbing it again. Use a garden hose to thoroughly rinse the patio off and allow it to dry completely before proceeding.

steps.headline: Use a roller brush to apply the stain to your patio.
steps.description: Start at the center of the patio and work outwards, or from the enclosed edge to the free edge, making sure to apply even layers and keeping a wet edge. Allowing the stain to dry during the process will create lines in your work, so work quickly to avoid this. Pour some stain into a shallow tray. Dip the roller brush into the stain and coat it evenly. Don't put too much stain on the brush because it can cause drips and make your work area messy. Roll the brush along the surface of the concrete in short, even strokes. Once you have the area completely coated with the stain, allow it to dry before adding additional coats. You will need a minimum of two coats, but you can add a third coat depending on the look you desire.

steps.headline: Break up your old concrete patio with a sledgehammer or jackhammer.
steps.description: These broken pieces of concrete will become your new “tiles.” Choose the tool based on the look you want. For tiles in various sizes, use a sledgehammer. For tiles more similar in size and a more uniform look, use a small jackhammer for more control. Be sure to use protective eyewear to protect yourself from flying pieces of concrete. As you break up the concrete, set the pieces aside from the area you are working so you can prep the ground for reinstallation.

steps.headline: Dig out a layer of earth where you will lay your patio.
steps.description: Dig down about 4–6 inches (10–15 cm), being sure to keep the area level. This space will be filled with sand or pea gravel to allow for drainage and to support the concrete tiles, and then will be topped with the tiles. You can keep the same size and/or shape as your original patio. If you decide to change things up, like making the area bigger or smaller, adding rounded edges, or creating a completely different shape, this would be the time to do it.

steps.headline: Add a layer of landscaping fabric to prevent weeds from growing.
steps.description: This step is a smart option, but it isn't required. Adding the protective barrier will save you time and money on upkeep later.

steps.headline: Spread sand or pea gravel on top of the earth using a shovel and rake.
steps.description: Use the shovel to pour small mounds of sand or gravel around the area, and use the rake to spread it around the surface area. This layer should slightly slope away from the house or structure to avoid puddles and standing water.

steps.headline: Place the concrete tiles on top of the prepped area.
steps.description: Starting from the outside edge and working inwards, lay the tiles on top of the sand/gravel, with the smooth side up. Leave about 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space in between each one. Aside from spacing, there is no right or wrong way to do this--just place the tiles in a way that is visually appealing to you. Think of it as a giant puzzle. You may have to move some pieces around until you get the right look and fit. If any of the concrete pieces are too thick, causing the surface to be unlevel, use a rubber mallet to hammer the piece further down into the ground.

steps.headline: Secure the concrete in place with sand to avoid shifting.
steps.description: Use a broom to push coarse sand across the patio, allowing it to fall into the spaces between the concrete tiles. The sand completes the look of your new recycled patio and also allows water to drain. Allow the sand to settle for a day or two, then repeat this step to fill in any gaps or spaces. For a different look, you may opt to fill in the spaces with grout or mortar as well.

steps.headline: Decorate to create a new look in your fresh space.
steps.description:
Consider whether you want a space for entertaining, or a place to relax and unwind. Depending on spacing and your budget, you have infinite options here. All you need is your sense of style and some creativity. Some ideas include:
Laying down an outdoor area rug
Making a succulent garden in a large pot
Setting up a fire pit

steps.headline: Splurge on a new set of patio furniture.
steps.description: Large rectangular tables are good for outside meals and family gatherings, while smaller circular tables are good for more intimate conversation. For visual interest, add an brightly-colored umbrella with a fun floral or geometric pattern. If your space will be used for frequent entertaining, think about adding a small bar area or outdoor couches for additional seating.

steps.headline: Display potted plants or flowers for variety.
steps.description: Plant annuals like petunias, zinnias, or geranium in pots and place around the patio. Consider buying or making a hanging basket for added interest. In a surrounding flower bed, add some low-maintenance perennials that will return every year. Good options for spring blooms are tulips or lillies. For summer and fall blooms, try coneflowers or daisies.

steps.headline: Add lighting for a relaxing atmosphere in the evenings.
steps.description: Hang string lights in a zig-zag or horizontal pattern across your patio to create a warm ambiance. You can also consider adding solar pathway lights along the edges of the patio. Place decorative citronella candles on the tables to provide beautiful lighting while also keeping mosquitoes away.
